snippet: Beijing, which reported growth of 7.4 percent for 2014, below its target of 7.5 percent, is trying to reduce its dependence on credit-fueled investment and government spending.
abstract: China's economy grew by 7.3 percent in fourth quarter 2014 and 7.4 percent for full year, missing its goal of 7.5 percent; nation is pinning hopes on consumer spending to drive growth; spending constitutes 36 percent of gross domestic product.

byline.contributor: Michael Forsythe contributed reporting from Hong Kong. Mia Li contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Beijing, which reported growth of 7.4 percent for 2014, below its target of 7.5 percent, is trying to reduce its dependence on credit-fueled investment and government spending.

headline.main: As Growth Slows, China Pins Hopes on Consumer Spending
headline.print_headline: As Growth Slows, China Pins Hopes on Consumer Spending
